prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Given the large number of antennas available in Cycle 2, we will have sufficient (u, v) coverage for imaging once we reach the requested sensitivity. To facilitate comparisons between the different lines and resolve the nuclei, we ask for matching ~1" angular resolution in both Bands 3 and 6 for VV 114. This value ensures that the nuclei are well-separated in the final maps, but also resolves out most of the flux unassociated with the AGN. Since the molecular torus surrounding an AGN is predicted to be < ~300~pc (e.g., Honig et al. 2006), we do not expect missing flux to be an issue at this resolution. Our proposed science requires uniform sensitivity for the two nuclei that are separated by ~13". Thus, we are requesting to image a retangular field that requires three ALMA pointings.
Greves et al. (2009) found that the HCN(1-0) to 12CO(2-1) and HCO+(1-0) to 12CO(2-1) line ratios to be in the range of ~0.01 in LIRGs. We expect the velocity-integrated HCN and HCO+(1-0) fluxes for VV114 to be ~11 Jy km/s as previous SMA observations indicate that the 12CO(2-1) emission in VV 114 is 1109 Jy km/s (Wilson et al. 2008). Assuming a velocity width of 300 km/s, the expected line peak flux is ~3 mJy per beam. We will use the 0.5 GHz baseband for this science goal which will provide ample velocity coverage (> 1000 km/s) for the line. The 0.25 MHz channel resolution at ~88 GHz gives a spectral resolution of ~0.8 km/s which we will average to 20 km/s channels for our analysis. The desired sensitivity of 0.6 mJy ensures an SNR of at least 5 sigma. The expected fluxes and desired sensitivity are summarized in Table 2 of the Scientific Justification.

Given the large number of antennas available in Cycle 2, we will have sufficient (u, v) coverage for imaging once we reach the requested sensitivity. To facilitate comparisons between the different lines and resolve the nuclei, we ask for matching ~1" angular resolution in both Bands 3 and 6 for VV 114. This value ensures that the nuclei are well-separated in the final maps, but also resolves out most of the flux unassociated with the AGN. Since the molecular torus surrounding an AGN is predicted to be < ~300~pc (e.g., Honig et al. 2006), we do not expect missing flux to be an issue at this resolution. Our proposed science requires uniform sensitivity for the two nuclei that are separated by ~13". Thus, we are requesting to image a retangular field that requires three ALMA pointings.
Greves et al. (2009) found that the HCN(3-2) to 12CO(2-1) and HCO+(3-2) to 12CO(2-1) line ratios to be in the range of 0.003 - 0.1 in ULIRGs. Taking the more conservative ratio of 0.03, we expect the velocity-integrated HCN and HCO+(3-2) fluxes for VV114 to be ~33 Jy km/s as previous SMA observations indicate that the 12CO(2-1) emission in VV 114 is 1109 Jy km/s (Wilson et al. 2008). Assuming a velocity width of 300 km/s, the expected line peak flux is ~7 mJy per beam. We will use the 1 GHz baseband for this science goal which will provide ample velocity coverage (> 1000 km/s) for the line. The 0.5 MHz channel resolution at ~240 GHz gives a spectral resolution of ~0.6 km/s which we will average to 20 km/s channels for our analysis. The desired sensitivity of 1 mJy ensures an SNR of at least 5 sigma. The expected fluxes and desired sensitivity are summarized in Table 2 of the Scientific Justification.

Given the large number of antennas available in Cycle 2, we will have sufficient (u, v) coverage for imaging once we reach the requested sensitivity. To facilitate comparisons between the different lines and resolve the nuclei, we ask for matching ~1" angular resolution in both Bands 3 and 6 for VV 114. This value ensures that the nuclei are well-separated in the final maps, but also resolves out most of the flux unassociated with the AGN. Since the molecular torus surrounding an AGN is predicted to be < ~300~pc (e.g., Honig et al. 2006), we do not expect missing flux to be an issue at this resolution. Our proposed science requires uniform sensitivity for the two nuclei that are separated by ~13". Thus, we are requesting to image a retangular field that requires three ALMA pointings.
Previous SMA observations indicate that the 12CO(2-1) emission in VV 114 is 1109 Jy km/s with a line width of ~600 km/s (Wilson et al. 2008). The weaker nucleus has a peak flux of ~0.6 Jy for a 4" beam. Assuming the requested 1" resolution for our observations of VV 114 and even distribution of the flux, the expected peak flux of the weaker component is ~0.04 Jy / beam. We will use the 1 GHz baseband for this science goal which will provide ample velocity coverage (> 1000 km/s) for the line. The 0.5 MHz channel resolution at ~240 GHz gives a spectral resolution of ~0.6 km/s which we will average to 20 km/s channels for our analysis. The desired sensitivity is 5 mJy for a channel SNR of at least 5 sigma. The expected fluxes and desired sensitivity are summarized in Table 2 of the Scientific Justification. In addition to our primary target lines, to improve the scientific return this pointing, we also set up the correlator to observe VV 114 in the high density tracer CS(5-4).

Given the large number of antennas available in Cycle 2, we will have sufficient (u, v) coverage for imaging once we reach the requested sensitivity. To facilitate comparisons between the different lines and resolve the nuclei, we ask for matching ~1.5" angular resolution in both Bands 3 and 6 for NGC 3256. This value ensures that the nuclei are well-separated in the final maps, but also resolves out most of the flux unassociated with the AGN. Since the molecular torus surrounding an AGN is predicted to be < ~300~pc (e.g., Honig et al. 2006), we do not expect missing flux to be an issue at this resolution.
Greves et al. (2009) found that the HCN(1-0) to 12CO(2-1) and HCO+(1-0) to 12CO(2-1) line ratios to be in the range of ~0.01 in LIRGs. We expect the velocity-integrated HCN and HCO+(1-0) fluxes for NGC 3256 to be ~33 Jy km/s as previous SMA observations indicate that the 12CO(2-1) emission in NGC 3256 is 4100 Jy km/s (Sakamoto et al. 2006). Assuming a velocity width of 300 km/s, the expected line peak flux is ~4 mJy per beam. We will use the 0.5 GHz baseband for this science goal which will provide ample velocity coverage (> 1000 km/s) for the line. The 0.25 MHz channel resolution at ~88 GHz gives a spectral resolution of ~0.8 km/s which we will average to 20 km/s channels for our analysis. The desired sensitivity of 0.8 mJy ensures an SNR of at least 5 sigma. The expected fluxes and desired sensitivity are summarized in Table 2 of the Scientific Justification.

Given the large number of antennas available in Cycle 2, we will have sufficient (u, v) coverage for imaging once we reach the requested sensitivity. To facilitate comparisons between the different lines and resolve the nuclei, we ask for matching ~1.5" angular resolution in both Bands 3 and 6 for NGC 3256. This value ensures that the nuclei are well-separated in the final maps, but also resolves out most of the flux unassociated with the AGN. Since the molecular torus surrounding an AGN is predicted to be < ~300~pc (e.g., Honig et al. 2006), we do not expect missing flux to be an issue at this resolution.
Greves et al. (2009) found that the HCN(3-2) to 12CO(2-1) and HCO+(3-2) to 12CO(2-1) line ratios to be in the range of 0.003 - 0.1 in LIRGs. Taking the more conservative ratio of 0.03, we expect the velocity-integrated HCN and HCO+(3-2) fluxes for NGC 3256 to be ~123 Jy km/s as previous SMA observations indicate that the 12CO(2-1) emission in NGC 3256 is 4100 Jy km/s (Sakamoto et al. 2006). Assuming a velocity width of 400 km/s, the expected line peak flux is ~12 mJy per beam. We will use the 1 GHz baseband for this science goal which will provide ample velocity coverage (> 1000 km/s) for the line. The 0.5 MHz channel resolution at ~240 GHz gives a spectral resolution of ~0.6 km/s which we will average to 20 km/s channels for our analysis. The desired sensitivity of 2 mJy ensures an SNR of at least 5 sigma. The expected fluxes and desired sensitivity are summarized in Table 2 of the Scientific Justification.

Given the large number of antennas available in Cycle 2, we will have sufficient (u, v) coverage for imaging once we reach the requested sensitivity. To facilitate comparisons between the different lines and resolve the nuclei, we ask for matching ~1.5" angular resolution in both Bands 3 and 6 for NGC 3256. This value ensures that the nuclei are well-separated in the final maps, but also resolves out most of the flux unassociated with the AGN. Since the molecular torus surrounding an AGN is predicted to be < ~300~pc (e.g., Honig et al. 2006), we do not expect missing flux to be an issue at this resolution.
Previous SMA observations indicate that the Previous SMA observations indicate that the 12CO(2-1) emission in NGC 3256 is 4100 Jy km/s with a line width of ~600 km/s (Sakamoto et al. 2006). The peak flux of both nuclei is ~5.5 Jy for a 5" beam. Resolved maps indicates the peak flux of the weaker nucleus is about half that of the stronger nucleus. Assuming the requested 1.5" resolution for our observations of NGC 3256 and even distribution of the flux, the expected peak flux of the weaker component is ~0.16 Jy / beam. We will use the 1 GHz baseband for this science goal which will provide ample velocity coverage (> 1000 km/s) for the line. The 0.5 MHz channel resolution at ~240 GHz gives a spectral resolution of ~0.6 km/s which we will average to 20 km/s channels for our analysis. The desired sensitivity is 5 mJy to match that of the VV114 observations. The expected fluxes and desired sensitivity are summarized in Table 2 of the Scientific Justification. In addition to our primary target lines, to improve the scientific return this pointing, we also set up the correlator to observe VV 114 in the high density tracer CS(5-4).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent theoretical and observational work suggests that black holes are responsible for the quenching of star formation in galaxies and the shaping of the observed properties in some early-type galaxies. It is therefore important to understand the number and evolution of black holes over cosmic time. Despite our best efforts, we still lack a complete census of black holes in the Universe. The cosmic X-ray background predicts a population of heavily obscured AGN that are comparable to the unobscured population, but our current techniques of quantifying (nearly) Compton-thick AGN are inadequate. This pilot program will observe two local mergers with distinct AGN and starburst nuclei. We wish to capitalize on ALMA's unprecedented sensitivity to identify heavily obscured AGN using molecular line transitions. Spatially resolved maps of dense gas tracers will be used to establish whether these transitions are sensitive to the nuclear luminosity. We will also characterize the physical conditions, such as gas turbulence, density, and temperature in the vicinity of the black hole using LVG analysis in order to understand the effects of active black holes on their environments.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Goddard Space Flight Center, National Aeronautics and Space Administration
